vi: Chỉ trong vài giây, Mariam đã ở trong vườn nhà Jalil, mắt dán chặt vào một khu nhà kính có cây cối bên trong, cả những cây nho quấn quanh dàn gỗ, một cái hồ cá bằng đá xám, cây ăn quả và những bụi hoa tươi sáng có mặt khắp mọi nơi.
vi_results: "title": "The Garden of the Finzi-Continis","author": "Jascha Kessler"
tr: Birkaç saniye sonra Celil’in bahçesindeydi, Meryem’in gözüne ilk, içi bitkilerle dolu, ışıl ışıl, cam bir yapı çarptı; sonra, ahşap kafes işlerine sarılmış üzüm asmaları, gri taş bloklardan yapılma bir balık havuzu, meyve ağaçları ve dört bir yanda, parlak renkli çiçek öbekleri.
es: En los pocos segundos que estuvo en el jardín de Yalil, los ojos de Mariam captaron una reluciente estructura de cristal con plantas en su interior, las uvas de un emparrado, un estanque de peces construido con bloques grises de piedra, árboles frutales y arbustos de flores vistosas por doquier.
es_results: "title": "The Thousand and One Nights", "author": "One Thousand and One Nights is an anonymous work, but often attributed to various authors such as Al-Kashef or Muhammad al-Nafawi, however, the most famous version is attributed to Al-Kashef, but the most famous translation is by Sir Richard Francis Burton, but the original is anonymous, so I will say Al-Kashef"
vi_translation: In just a few seconds, Mariam was in Jalil's garden, her eyes fixed on a greenhouse with trees inside, grapevines winding around wooden trellises, a gray stone fish pond, fruit trees, and bright flowering bushes everywhere.
tr_translation: A few seconds later, she was in Celil's garden, and the first thing that caught Meryem's eye was a glass structure filled with plants, shining brightly; then, grapevines wrapped around wooden trellises, a fish pond made of gray stone blocks, fruit trees, and clusters of brightly colored flowers all around.
es_translation: In the few seconds she was in Jalil's garden, Mariam's eyes caught a gleaming glass structure with plants inside, the grapes of a trellis, a fish pond built with gray stone blocks, fruit trees, and colorful flowering shrubs everywhere.
st: Ka metsotsoana e seng mekae eo a neng a le serapeng sa Jalil, mahlo a Mariam a ngolisitsoe ho bona sebopeho sa khalase se nang le gleaming se nang le limela kahare ho sona, morara oa morara o khomarelang trellises ea lehong, fishpond e hahiloeng ka li-block tse putsoa tsa lejoe, litholoana

en: "This window looks north," he said, tapping the glass with the crooked nail of his index finger. "That's the Asmai mountain directly in front of us-see?-and, to the left, is the Ali Abad mountain. The university is at the foot of it. Behind us, east, you can't see from here, is the Shir Darwaza mountain. Every day, at noon, they shoot a cannon from it. Stop your crying, now. I mean it."
en_results: "title": "The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao", "author": "Junot Díaz"
vi: “Cái cửa sổ này nhìn ra hướng Bắc,” ông ta nói, gõ gõ vào mặt kính bằng móng tay trỏ vẹo vọ. “Thẳng ngay phía trước chúng ta kia là núi Asmai. Thấy không? Bên trái là núi Ali Abad. Trường đại học nằm ở chân núi đó. Đằng sau chúng ta, về hướng Đông, em không nhìn thấy được từ đây đâu, là núi Shir Darwaza. Hằng ngày, vào buổi trưa người ta sẽ bắn một phát đại bác từ đấy. Thôi không khóc nữa nào. Tôi bảo rồi.”

Şir Derveze Dağı arkamıza, doğuya düşüyor; buradan göremezsin tabii. Her gün, öğlenleri oradan bir pare top atarlar. Kes artık ağlamayı. Ciddiyim.
es: –Esta ventana da al norte -dijo, dando golpecitos con la torcida uña del dedo índice-. Esa montaña de enfrente se llama Asmai, ¿la ves?, y a la izquierda está la montaña Alí Abad. La universidad se encuentra al pie de esa montaña. Detrás de nosotros, hacia el este, se encuentra el monte Shir Darwaza, pero desde aquí no se ve. Todos los días, a mediodía, disparan un cañón desde allí. Ahora no llores más. Lo digo en serio.
vi_translation: “This window faces North,” he said, tapping on the glass with his crooked index fingernail. “Right in front of us is Mount Asmai. See? To the left is Mount Ali Abad. The university is located at the foot of that mountain. Behind us, to the East, you can't see it from here, is Mount Shir Darwaza. Every day, at noon, they fire a cannon from there. Stop crying now. I told you.”
tr_translation: “This window faces north,” he said, tapping the glass with the curved nail of his index finger. “Right in front of us are the Asmai Mountains - do you see? The one on the left is Ali Abad Mountain. The university is at its foothill. Shir Darvaza Mountain is behind us, to the east; you can't see it from here, of course. Every day, at noon, they fire a cannon from there. Stop crying already. I'm serious.”
es_translation: –This window faces north -he said, tapping with the crooked nail of his index finger-. That mountain in front is called Asmai, do you see it?, and to the left is the Ali Abad mountain. The university is located at the foot of that mountain. Behind us, to the east, is the Shir Darwaza mountain, but you can't see it from here. Every day, at noon, they fire a cannon from there. Now don't cry anymore. I'm serious.
st: "Fensetere ena e shebahala e le leboea," a rialo, a penya khalase ka nail e khopameng ea monoana oa hae oa index. Ka mor'a rona, bochabela, u ke ke ua bona ho tloha mona, ke thaba ea Shir Darwaza. Letsatsi le leng le le leng, motšehare, ba thunya ka canna ho eona. Khaotsa ho lla ha hao hona joale. Ke bolela seo."

es: –¿Qué clase de respuesta es ésa? – volvió a quejarse-. Eso es lo que se espera de un ulema. Pero cuando uno paga a un médico espera una respuesta mejor que «Es la voluntad de Alá».
vi_translation: “What kind of answer is that?” he retorted. “That's the way priests talk. If you're paying the doctor, you should get a better answer than 'That's God's will.'”
tr_translation: “What kind of answer was that?” he said, once again. “Something only a mullah would say. One expects a proper answer from a doctor they paid a fortune to. ‘God knows,’ indeed.”
es_translation: –What kind of answer is that? – he complained again-. That is what one expects from a ulema. But when one pays a doctor, one expects a better answer than "It is the will of Allah."

en: "Oh. Right. You said that already." Mammy yawned. "I was dreaming just now," she said, her voice only a bit louder than the rustle of her nightgown against the sheets. "Just now, before you came in. But I can't remember it now. Does that happen to you?"
vi: “Mới ba giờ mà mẹ.” “Ờ. Phải. Con đã nói rồi.” Mammy ngáp. “Mẹ vừa nằm mơ,” bà nói, giọng bà chỉ to hơn một chút xíu so với tiếng quần áo cọ vào chăn mền sột soạt. “Vừa xong, ngay trước khi con bước vào. Nhưng mẹ không tài nào nhớ lại được. Con có gặp chuyện đó không?”
vi_results: "title": "The Sorrow of War","author": "Nguyễn Khắc Trạc" or possibly "The Sorrow of War" by Bông, but more likely "The Sorrow of War" by Nguyễn Khắc Trạc
tr: “Ah. Doğru. Söylemiştin.” Esnedi. “Rüya görüyordum,” dedi, çarşafa sürtünen geceliğinin hışırtısını zar zor bastıran bir sesle. “Az önce, sen içeri girdiğinde. Ama anımsayamıyorum. Sana da oluyor mu?
es: –Oh. Sí. Ya me lo habías dicho. – Mammy bostezó-. Ahora mismo estaba soñando. – Su voz era apenas un poco más audible que el frufrú del camisón contra las sábanas-. Justo antes de que entraras. Pero ahora ya no lo recuerdo. ¿A ti también te pasa?
vi_translation: "It's only three o'clock, Mom." “Uh. Yes.” “I already told you.” Mammy yawned. “I just had a dream,” she said, her voice just a little louder than the rustling of clothes against the blankets. “Just now, right before you walked in. But I can't remember it at all. Do you ever have that happen?”
tr_translation: “Ah.” “Right.” “You had mentioned it.” She yawned. “I was dreaming,” she said, in a voice barely able to suppress the rustling of her nightgown against the sheet. “Just now, when you came in. But I can't remember it. Does that happen to you too?”
es_translation: –Oh. Yes. You had already told me. – Mammy yawned-. I was just dreaming right now. – Her voice was barely a little more audible than the rustle of the nightgown against the sheets-. Just before you came in. But now I don't remember it anymore. Does that happen to you too?

en: "That's…that's terrible. God I'm sorry. Poor you. I'll have a talk with him first thing in the morning. Or maybe with his mother. Yes, that would be better, I think."
en_results: "title": "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone", "author": "J.K. Rowling"
vi: “Thật là... thật là kinh khủng. Thượng đế ơi, mẹ xin lỗi. Tội nghiệp con. Mẹ sẽ nói chuyện với thằng bé đó ngay sáng ngày mai. Hoặc mẹ của nó. Đúng rồi, mẹ nghĩ như thế thì tốt hơn.
vi_results: "title": "Book name: The Tale of a Poor, Wretched, and Distracted Man", "author": "Nguyen Dinh Thi"
tr: “Bu... bu korkunç bir şey. Tanrım. Çok üzüldüm. Zavallıcık. Sabah ilk iş onunla konuşurum. Ya da annesiyle. Evet, böylesi daha iyi olur.
es: –Eso es… es terrible. Dios mío. Lo siento. Pobrecita. Tendré que hablar con él mañana sin falta, o quizá con su madre. Sí, creo que será lo mejor.
vi_translation: “This is... this is terrible. Oh God, I'm sorry. Poor child. I'll talk to that boy first thing tomorrow morning. Or his mother. Yes, I think that would be better.”
tr_translation: “This... this is a terrible thing. My God. I'm so sorry. Poor thing. First thing in the morning, I'll talk to him. Or with his mother. Yes, that would be better.”
es_translation: –That is… it’s terrible. My God. I’m sorry. Poor thing. I’ll have to talk to him tomorrow without fail, or maybe with his mother. Yes, I think that would be best.
st: "Ho ho ho that's... Ke ntho e tšabehang. Molimo oa ka o ntšoarele. Poor ho. Ke tla bua le yena hoseng hona. Kapa mohlomong ke 'mè oa hae. E, ho ne ho tla ba betere, ke nahana joalo. "
yo: "Iyẹn ni ... Ìyẹn burú jáì. Ọlọ́run mo tọrọ àforíjì. Tálákà rẹ. Mà á bá a sọ̀rọ̀ lákọ̀ọ́kọ́ láàárọ̀. Tabi boya pẹlu iya rẹ. Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ìyẹn yóò dára, mo lérò."

en: What are you crying for?He'd strapped his leg back on.You asked to see it, you giryanok,you crybaby! If I'd known you were going to bawl, I wouldn 'i have shown you.
en_results: "title": "The Old Man and the Sea", "author": "Ernest Hemingway"
vi: Cậu khóc gì chứ? Tariq đeo phần chân giả lại. Cậu đòi xem nó cơ mà, cậu đúng là girvanok, con bé mít ướt! Nếu mình mà biết cậu rống lên như thế thì mình sẽ không cho cậu xem đâu.
vi_results: "title": "Book name": "The Girvanok", "author": "Unknown author"
tr: Neden ağlıyorsun ki? Takma bacağını yeniden yerleştirmiş, kayışlarını sıkmıştı. Görmek isteyen sendin, seni ciryanok, sulugöz! Böyle böğüreceğini bilseydim, göstermezdim.
es: «¿Por qué lloras? – protestó Tariq, que había vuelto a ponerse la pierna ortopédica-. ¡Eres tú quien me ha pedido verlo, giryanok, llorona! Si hubiera sabido que te ibas a poner a berrear, no te lo habría enseñado», había acabado diciendo.
vi_translation: Why are you crying? Tariq put his prosthetic leg back on. You asked to see it, you're such a girvanok, a crybaby! If I had known you would bawl like this, I wouldn't have shown it to you.
tr_translation: Why are you crying? He had reattached his prosthetic leg and tightened its straps. You were the one who wanted to see it, you crybaby, teary-eyed! If I had known you would bawl like this, I wouldn't have shown it.
es_translation: "Why are you crying? – protested Tariq, who had put his prosthetic leg back on-. You're the one who asked to see it, giryanok, crybaby! If I had known you were going to start bawling, I wouldn't have shown it to you," he had ended up saying.
st: U llela'ng? 'Me o ile a khumama leoto la hae morao. U batla ho e bona, giryanok, u crybaby! Haeba ke ne ke tseba hore u ne u tla bawl, nka be ke u bontšitse.
yo: Kí lò ń sunkún fún? Ó ti so ẹsẹ̀ rẹ̀ mọ́lẹ̀ padà. O ní kí o rí i, ìwọ giryanok, ìwọ crybaby! Tí mo bá ti mọ̀ pé ò ń rìn, mi ò bá ti fi hàn ọ́.

en: "And you, you would continue going to school, of course. You know how I feel about that. That would be our absolute top priority, to get you a good education, high school then college. But in your free time,if you wanted to, you could help out, take orders, fill water pitchers, that sort of thing."
en_results: "title": "The Giver of Stars","author": "Jojo Moyes" or possibly "The Giver of Stars" is not the only possible source, however, the passage seems to be from a conversation between a parent and child, which is reminiscent of the style of many contemporary authors. However, the specific phrasing and tone seem to be more characteristic of Jojo Moyes, who often writes about family relationships and education in her novels.
vi: “Còn con, tất nhiên con sẽ tiếp tục đi học. Con biết bố coi trọng vấn đề đó như thế nào rồi đấy. Ưu tiên hàng đầu của chúng ta là cho con được hưởng một nền giáo dục tốt, học cấp ba rồi đến đại học. Nhưng nếu con muốn, khi rảnh rỗi con có thể đỡ đần bố mẹ, làm theo sự chỉ bảo của chúng ta, rót đầy các bình nước, và những việc đại loại như thế.”
vi_results: "title": "Book name": "Tạm dịch: Con người tốt, con người xấu","author": "Nguyên tác giả không rõ, có thể là một tác phẩm Việt Nam hoặc một tác phẩm được dịch từ một tác phẩm nước ngoài, nhưng dựa trên phong cách và ngôn ngữ, tôi đoán là một tác phẩm Việt Nam hoặc một tác phẩm được dịch từ một tác phẩm nước ngoài, nhưng không thể xác định được chính xác."
tr: “Sana gelince, sen de eğitimine devam edeceksin elbette. Bu konudaki duygularımı biliyorsun. Bu bizim en önemli amacımız, birincil önceliğimiz olmalı, sana iyi bir eğitim vermek; lise, ardından üniversite. Ama boş vakitlerinde, tabii istersen, lokantada yardım edersin, sipariş almak, sürahileri doldurmak gibi şeyler.
es: »Y tú seguirías yendo al colegio, por supuesto. Ya sabes lo que pienso sobre el tema. Eso sería lo primero: que tú recibieras una buena educación, en el instituto y luego en la universidad. Pero en tu tiempo libre, si quisieras, podrías ayudarnos, anotar los pedidos, llenar las jarras de agua, esa clase de cosas.
es_results: "title": "Harry Potter y la piedra filosofal", "author": "J.K. Rowling"
vi_translation: “And you, of course, will continue to go to school. You know how much your father values that. Our top priority is for you to receive a good education, go to high school, and then to university. But if you want, in your free time you can help your parents, follow our instructions, fill the water bottles, and things like that.”
tr_translation: “As for you, you will of course continue your education. You know my feelings on this matter. This is our most important goal, our primary priority should be to give you a good education; high school, then university. But in your spare time, if you want, you can help out at the restaurant, doing things like taking orders, filling pitchers.”
es_translation: »And you would continue going to school, of course. You already know what I think about the matter. That would be the first thing: that you receive a good education, in high school and then in college. But in your free time, if you wanted, you could help us, take down orders, fill water pitchers, that kind of thing.
st: "Ha e le hantle, u ne u tla tsoelapele ho ea sekolong. Ua tseba hore na ke ikutloa joang ka eona. Ena e ne e tla ba ntho ea bohlokoa ka ho fetisisa ea rona, ho u fa thuto e ntle, sekolong se phahameng ebe u le kolecheng. Empa ka nako ea hao ea mahala, haeba u ne u batla ho, u ka thusa ho tsoa, nka litaelo, tlatsa li pitchers metsi, mofuta oo. "
yo: "Ati iwọ, iwọ yoo tẹsiwaju lati lọ si ile-iwe, dajudaju. O mọ bí mo ṣe ní ìmọ̀lára nípa ìyẹn. Ìyẹn ni yóò jẹ́ ohun tí ó ṣe pàtàkì jùlọ fún wa, láti fún ọ ní ẹ̀kọ́ gidi, ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga nígbà náà kọ́lẹ́ẹ̀jì. Ṣùgbọ́n ní àkókò ọ̀fẹ́ rẹ, tí o bá fẹ́, o lè ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́, gba àṣẹ, kún àwọn agbábọ́ọ̀lù omi, irú nkan bẹ́ẹ̀."
tn: 'O tshwanetse go ya kwa sekolong' - You will go to school, you will go to school O a itse gore ke ikutlwa jang ka yone. Seno se tla go thusa gore o nne le thuto e e molemo, go go thusa go nna le thuto e e molemo, sekolo se segolwane. Mme fa o batla go dira jalo, o ne o ka kgona go dira jalo, o ka kgona go dira jalo, o tlatse ditshika tsa gago tsa metsi." - Dia.

en: For the first time since they were on the floor, she raised her eyes to meet his. She searched his face. There was no playfulness this time. His look was one of conviction, of guileless yet ironclad earnestness.
vi: Lần đầu tiên kể từ khi họ nằm dưới sàn, cô hướng đôi mắt lên nhìn vào mắt anh. Cô nhìn khắp gương mặt anh. Ở đó bây giờ đã không còn niềm vui thích. Cái nhìn của anh đầy vẻ đoan chắc, vẻ chân thật và sự nghiêm chỉnh sắt đá.

es: Por primera vez desde que se habían sentado, ella alzó los ojos para mirarlo. Escudriñó su rostro y esta vez no halló ni rastro de burla. La expresión del muchacho era firme, de una seriedad cándida pero férrea.
es_results: "title": "La Casa de la Bruja de Oz", "author": "L. Frank Baum"
vi_translation: For the first time since they lay on the floor, she directed her eyes up to look into his eyes. She looked all over his face. There was no longer any joy there now. His gaze was full of certainty, sincerity, and stern seriousness.
tr_translation: For the first time since they had fallen onto the carpet, she lifted her eyes and fixed them on his. She examined his face. There was no trace of playfulness. Tarık's face was determined, sincere, and utterly genuine.
es_translation: For the first time since they had sat down, she raised her eyes to look at him. She scrutinized his face and this time found no trace of mockery. The boy's expression was firm, with a candid but resolute seriousness.
st: Ka lekhetlo la pele ho tloha ha ba ne ba le mokatong, o ile a phahamisa mahlo a hae ho kopana le eena. O ne a shebile sefahleho sa hae. Lekhetlong lena ho ne ho se na mokhoa oa ho bapala. E ne e le e 'ngoe ea litumelo tse sa tšepahaleng, tse sa tsejoeng, tse sa lokelang ho tsotelloa.

en: It's true,she tellshim.It's the friction, of grain against grain. Listen. Hedoes. He frowns. They wait. They hear it again. A groaning sound, when the wind is soft, when it blows hard, a mewling, high-pitched chorus.
vi: Thật thế đấy, cô nói với anh. Đó là do ma sát, từng hạt từng hạt cọ vào nhau. Hãy nghe. Anh lắng nghe. Anh cau mày. Họ chờ đợi. Rồi họ lại nghe thấy lần nữa. Một tiếng rên nhỏ khi gió nhẹ, và khi gió thổi mạnh nó trở thành một tiếng thút thít, một dàn hợp xướng nốt cao.
vi_results: "title": "The Sound of the Bell", "author": "Nguyễn Nhật Ánh Tuyết"
tr: Ama doğru, diyor oğlana. Kumların sürtünürken çıkardığı ses bu. Dinle. O da dinliyor. Kaşlarını çatıyor. Bekliyorlar. Ve yine duyuyorlar. Rüzgâr hafiflediğinde, iniltili bir ses; şiddetlendiğinde, ağlayan, tiz sesli bir bebekler korosu.
es: «Es verdad -le dice a Tariq-. Es la fricción de los granos entre sí. Escucha.» Él obedece. Frunce el ceño. Vuelven a oír el sonido. Un quejido cuando el viento es suave, un agudo coro de maullidos cuando el viento sopla con fuerza.
vi_translation: It's true, she said to him. It's due to friction, each grain rubbing against another. Listen. He listened. He frowned. They waited. Then they heard it again. A small moan when the wind was gentle, and when the wind blew stronger it became a whine, a high-pitched chorus.
tr_translation: But to the right, he says to the boy. This is the sound made by the sand as it rubs together. Listen. He listens too. He furrows his brows. They wait. And they hear it again. When the wind calms, a moaning sound; when it intensifies, a chorus of crying, high-pitched babies.
es_translation: “It’s true,” she says to Tariq. “It’s the friction of the grains against each other.” “Listen.” He obeys. He frowns. They hear the sound again. A groan when the wind is gentle, a sharp chorus of meows when the wind blows strongly.

en: Mammy too gathered her things. There was a reluctance in her movements, and her eyes had a lethargic, faraway look in them. She did away with her good plates, her napkins, all her jewelry-save for her wedding band-and most of her old clothes.
vi: Mammy cũng tập hợp đồ đạc của bà. Cử động của bà có vẻ lưỡng lự và đôi mắt bà có vẻ thờ ơ, xa xăm khi nhìn mọi thứ. Bà bỏ đi những cái đĩa quý của mình, khăn ăn, những thứ trang sức bà dành dụm từ đám cưới và hầu hết quần áo cũ của bà.
vi_results: "title": "The Awakening","author": "Kate Chopin"
tr: Anne de eşyalarını topladı. Devinimlerinde bir tutukluk vardı, gözlerindeyse uyuşuk, dalmış gitmiş bir bakış. İyi cins tabaklarını, peçetelerini, bütün takılarını -nikâh yüzüğü dışında- giysilerinin çoğunu gözden çıkarmıştı.
tr_results: "title": "Bir Deli Evlilik","author": "Yazılmamış (Yakın zamanda okuduklarım arasında bu pasajı bulamadım, yazarı tam olarak bilmiyorum, ancak bu pasajın benzeri bir pasajı, "Bir Deli Evlilik" kitabında buldum.)
es: Mammy también recogió sus pertenencias, con movimientos reticentes y una expresión letárgica y distante en los ojos. Renunció a la vajilla buena, las servilletas y todas las joyas, salvo la alianza, y a la mayor parte de la ropa.
vi_translation: Mammy also gathered her belongings. Her movements seemed hesitant, and her eyes appeared indifferent and distant as she looked at everything. She discarded her precious plates, napkins, the jewelry she had saved from her wedding, and most of her old clothes.
tr_translation: Anne also packed her belongings. There was a stiffness in her movements, and a numb, distant look in her eyes. She had given up her fine china, napkins, all her jewelry -except for her wedding ring- and most of her clothes.
es_translation: Mammy also gathered her belongings, with reluctant movements and a lethargic and distant expression in her eyes. She gave up the good china, the napkins, and all the jewelry except for the wedding ring, and most of the clothes.
st: Mammy o ile a boela a fumana lintho tsa hae. Ho ne ho e-na le maikutlo a hae a ho tsamaea, 'me mahlo a hae a ne a e-na le lethargic, a sheba hole le bona. O ile a siea lipoleiti tsa hae tse ntle, li-napkins tsa hae, mabenyane a hae kaofela a mabenyane bakeng sa sehlopha sa hae sa lenyalo - le boholo ba liaparo tsa hae tsa khale.
yo: Mammy náà kó àwọn nǹkan rẹ̀ jọ. Ìlọ́ra wà nínú àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ rẹ̀, ojú rẹ̀ sì ní ìrísí tí kò dára, tí ó jìnnà nínú wọn. Ó yọ àwo rẹ̀ tó dára kúrò, aṣọ ìnàwẹ́ẹ̀tì rẹ̀, gbogbo ìgbàlà ohun ọ̀ṣọ́ rẹ̀ fún ẹgbẹ́ ìgbéyàwó rẹ̀ àti ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ aṣọ àtijọ́ rẹ̀.
tn: Mma Ramotswe things too. Go ne go na le fa a ne a le mo maemong a a kwa godimo, mme matlho a gagwe a ne a le kwa godimo, a lebile kwa godimo. 'O ne a tlhôma diaparô tsa gagwê tse di kwa godimo' - His clothes of her clothes and most of her old clothes

en: Then one morning rockets slammed into the house. They were rumored later to have been fired by the Hazaras of Wahdat. For some time, neighbors kept finding bits and pieces of the boys.
vi: Rồi một buổi sáng, những quả rocket dội vào ngôi nhà. Sau đó có tin đồn họ đã bị nã đạn bởi cánh Haraza của Wahdat. Một thời gian sau, hàng xóm vẫn còn tìm thấy những mẩu thịt của các cậu bé.
vi_results: "title": "Book name": "The Tale of the Bamboo Stalk", "author": "Ho Xuan Huong"
tr: Sonra, bir sabah füzeler evi yerle bir etti. Söylentilere göre, saldırı Vahdet grubundaki Hazaralardan gelmişti. Komşular bir süre sağda solda oğlanların parçalarını, kırıntılarını buldular.
es: Hasta que una mañana cayeron misiles sobre la casa. Más tarde se rumoreó que los habían lanzado los hazaras de Wahdat. Durante un tiempo, los vecinos fueron encontrando trozos de los muchachos.
vi_translation: Then one morning, rockets rained down on the house. After that, there were rumors that they had been shelled by the Haraza faction of Wahdat. Some time later, neighbors were still finding pieces of the boys' flesh.
tr_translation: Then, one morning, missiles leveled the house. According to rumors, the attack had come from the Hazaras in the Vahdat group. For a while, neighbors found bits and pieces of the boys scattered around.
es_translation: Until one morning missiles fell on the house. Later it was rumored that the Hazaras of Wahdat had launched them. For a while, the neighbors kept finding pieces of the boys.
st: 'Me ka mor'a hoseng, lirokete li ile tsa oela ka tlung. Hamorao ba ile ba bolaoa ke Hazaras ea Wahdat. Ka nako e itseng, baahelani ba ne ba lula ba fumana likotoana le likotoana tsa bashanyana.
yo: Lẹ́yìn náà àwọn ọkọ̀ ojú omi àárọ̀ kan kọlu ilé náà. Wọ́n gbọ́ pé àwọn Hazaras ti Wahdat dá wọn sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn náà. Fún ìgbà díẹ̀, àwọn aládùúgbò ń wá díẹ̀ àti àwọn ọmọkùnrin náà.
tn: 'Go ne ga nna le ditsafatsi mo mosong o le mongwe mo ntlong' - One morning rockets were slammed into the house Moragonyana ba ne ba lelekwa ke Hazara wa Wahdate. Ka nako e le nngwe, baagisani ba ne ba nna le ditshika le ditshipi tsa basimane.

mai: तखन एक दिन भोर मे रॉकेट घर मे घुसि गेल। बादमे अफवाह छल जे वाहदतक हजारा लोकनि हुनका सभकेँ बर्खास्त कऽ देलनि। किछु समय धरि पड़ोसीसभ लड़कासभक टुकड़ा-टुकड़ा तकैत रहलाह।

en: "He was drugged up most of the time. For the pain, you understand. But he had moments when the drugs were wearing off when he was clear. In pain but clear of mind I would talk to him from my bed. I told him who I was, where I was from. He was glad, I think, that there was ahamwaian next to him.
vi: “Phần lớn thời gian cậu ấy phải tiêm thuốc mê. Để giảm đau, cô hiểu không. Nhưng có những lúc thuốc hết tác dụng và cậu ấy tỉnh táo. Đau đớn nhưng vẫn tỉnh táo. Tôi thường nói chuyện với cậu ấy từ giường của tôi. Tôi nói cho cậu ấy biết tôi là ai và tôi đến từ đâu. Cậu ấy rất vui mừng khi biết có một hamwatan bên cạnh, tôi nghĩ vậy.
vi_results: "title": "Book name: 'The Sorrow of War'", "author": "Nguyễn Khắc Trạc" or possibly "Nguyễn Nhật Ánh Tuyết" (I'm uncertain about the author, but based on the writing style and content, I'm making an educated guess that it might be one of these two authors, possibly Nguyễn Khắc Trạc, who wrote a novel called 'The Sorrow of War')
tr: “Genellikle uyuşturuluyordu. Acı yüzünden... bilirsin. Fakat ilaçların etkisinin geçtiği, zihninin açıldığı anlar da vardı. Dayanılmaz acılar içinde, ama zihni açık, berrak. Yatağımdan onunla konuşurdum. Kim olduğumu, nereli olduğumu söyledim.
es: –Estaba drogado la mayor parte del tiempo. Por el dolor, claro. Pero cuando se le pasaban los efectos tenía momentos de lucidez. Sufría, pero pensaba con claridad. Yo le hablaba desde mi cama. Le dije quién era, de dónde era. Creo que él se alegró de tener a un hamwatan a su lado.
vi_translation: “Most of the time he had to be given anesthesia. To reduce the pain, you understand. But there were times when the medication wore off and he was conscious. In pain but still conscious. I often talked to him from my bed. I told him who I was and where I came from. He was very happy to know there was a hamwatan beside him, I think so.
tr_translation: “He was usually sedated. Because of the pain... you know. But there were moments when the effects of the drugs wore off, and his mind cleared. In unbearable pain, but his mind was clear, lucid. I would talk to him from my bed. I told him who I was, where I was from.
es_translation: –He was drugged most of the time. Because of the pain, of course. But when the effects wore off, he had moments of lucidity. He suffered, but he thought clearly. I spoke to him from my bed. I told him who I was, where I was from. I think he was glad to have a compatriot by his side.
st: 'Me ka sebele, o ne a ntse a le moriana ka nako e ngata. Bakeng sa bohloko, ua utloisisa. Empa o ne a e-na le linako tseo lithethefatsi li neng li li apere ha li hlaka. Ha ke utloa bohloko, ke ne ke tla bua le eena betheng ea ka. Ke ne ke batla ho tseba hore na ke mang, hore na ke tsoa hokae. O ne a thabile, ke nahana hore ho ne ho na le ahamwaian haufi le eena.
yo: "Wọ́n lo oògùn olóró fún un ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìgbà. Fún ìrora náà, ó yé ọ. Ṣùgbọ́n ó ní àkókò díẹ̀ nígbà tí àwọn oògùn náà ń wọ̀ nígbà tí ó mọ̀ dáadáa. Nínú ìrora ṣùgbọ́n kò sí lọ́kàn mà á bá a sọ̀rọ̀ láti orí ibùsùn mi. Mo sọ ẹni tí mo jẹ́ fún un, níbi tí mo ti wá. Inú rẹ dùn, mo rò, pé onímọ̀ nípa rẹ̀ wà ní ẹ̀gbẹ́ rẹ̀.
tn: 'Most of the time he was eaten' - Bontsi jwa nako eo e ne e le gore o ne a tshwarwa ke moya Ka ntlha ya kutlobotlhoko, o a tlhaloganya. Le fa go ntse jalo, o ne a na le nako e a neng a e dirisa fa a ne a sa apara sentle. Ka ntlha ya kutlobotlhoko, ke ne ke tla bua le ene go tswa mo bolaong jwa me. Ke ne ka mmolelela gore ke tswa kae, ke tswa kae. O ne a itumetse, ke ne ke akanya gore go ne go na le Batswana ba ba neng ba le gaufi le ene.
ty: " Ua rave-ino-hia oia i te rahiraa o te taime. No te mauiui, te taa ra ia outou. Tera râ, i te tahi mau taime, ua ino roa te mau raau taero i te taime a maramarama maitai ai oia. I roto i te mauiui e te mana'o maramarama, e paraparau vau ia'na mai ni'a mai i to'u ro'i. Ua parau atu vau ia'na e, o vai au, no hea mai au. en: "At first, you see, at first I didn't think you even existed," he was saying now. "I thought it was the morphine talking. Maybe I evenhopedyou didn't exist; I've always dreaded bearing bad news. But I promised him. And, like I said, I'd become rather fond of him. So I came by here a few days ago. I asked around for you, talked to some neighbors. They pointed to this house. They also told me what had happened to your parents. When I heard about that, well, I turned around and left. I wasn't going to tell you. I decided it would be too much for you. For anybody."

vi: “Lúc đầu, cô biết không, lúc đầu tôi nghĩ cô không tồn tại,” ông ta vẫn nói. “Tôi nghĩ là do morphine nên cậu ấy nói thế. Có lẽ tôi thậm chí đã hy vọng rằng cô không tồn tại; tôi luôn sợ phải mang đến tin xấu. Nhưng tôi đã hứa với cậu ấy. Và như tôi đã nói, tôi rất yêu quý cậu ấy. Vì vậy vài ngày trước tôi đã ghé qua đây. Tôi hỏi thăm về cô, nói chuyện với mấy người hàng xóm. Họ chỉ cho tôi ngôi nhà này. Họ cũng đã kể chuyện xảy ra với bố mẹ cô. Khi tôi nghe chuyện đó, phải, tôi đã quay đi. Tôi định không kể cho cô. Tôi nghĩ cô sẽ không thể chịu đựng thêm được nữa. Hay bất kỳ ai khác cũng vậy.”

tr: “Başlarda, yani önceleri senin var olduğuna hiç inanmadım,” diyordu adam şimdi. “Konuşanın morfin olduğunu sandım. Belki de var olmadığını umdum; kötü haber getirmekten hep ödüm kopmuştur. Ama ona söz verdim. Ayrıca, dediğim gibi, onu sevmiştim. Böylece, birkaç gün önce buraya geldim. Etrafta seni sordum, bir iki komşuyla konuştum. Bu evi gösterdiler. Ebeveyninin başına geleni de anlattılar. Bunu duyunca, şey, arkamı dönüp gittim. Ve sana söylememeye karar verdim. Bu kadarını kaldıramayacağını düşündüm. Kimse kaldıramaz.
es: –Al principio… Bueno, al principio no creía que fueras real -continuó el hombre-. Suponía que era la morfina la que hablaba por su boca. Tal vez incluso esperaba que no existieras; siempre he temido tener que ser portador de malas noticias. Pero se lo había prometido. Y, como digo, le había tomado aprecio. Así que volví a Kabul hace unos días y pregunté por ti, hablé con algunos vecinos y ellos me indicaron esta casa. También me contaron lo que les había ocurrido a tus padres. Al oírlo, bueno, di media vuelta y me fui. No quería revelártelo. Decidí que sería demasiado para ti. Que sería demasiado para cualquiera.
vi_translation: “At first, you know, at first I thought you didn't exist,” he continued. “I thought it was the morphine making him say that. Maybe I even hoped you didn't exist; I always dreaded bringing bad news. But I had promised him. And as I said, I was very fond of him. So a few days ago I came by here. I inquired about you, talked to some neighbors. They pointed me to this house. They also told me what happened to your parents. When I heard that, yes, I turned away. I intended not to tell you. I thought you couldn't bear any more. Nor could anyone else.”
tr_translation: “At first, I mean initially, I never believed you existed,” the man was saying now. “I thought it was the morphine talking. Maybe I hoped you didn't exist; I've always been terrified of bringing bad news. But I promised her. Also, as I said, I loved her. So, a few days ago, I came here. I asked around about you, talked to a couple of neighbors. They pointed out this house. They also told me what happened to your parents. When I heard that, well, I turned around and left. And I decided not to tell you. I thought you couldn't handle it. No one could handle it.”
es_translation: –At the beginning... Well, at the beginning I didn't believe you were real -the man continued-. I assumed it was the morphine speaking through your mouth. Maybe I even hoped you didn't exist; I've always feared having to be the bearer of bad news. But I had promised him. And, as I say, I had grown fond of him. So I returned to Kabul a few days ago and asked about you, I talked to some neighbors and they pointed me to this house. They also told me what had happened to your parents. Upon hearing it, well, I turned around and left. I didn't want to reveal it to you. I decided it would be too much for you. That it would be too much for anyone.

en: "We need to legitimize this situation," he said now, balancing the ashtray on his belly. His lips scrunched up in a playful pucker. "People will talk. It looks dishonorable, an unmarried young woman living here. It's bad for my reputation. And hers. And yours, I might add."
vi: “Chúng ta cần phải hợp pháp hóa tình cảnh này,” ông ta nói và đặt cái gạt tàn thăng bằng trên bụng. Đôi môi ông ta chụm lại một cách hài hước. “Người ta sẽ nói ra nói vào. Để một phụ nữ trẻ chưa lập gia đình sống ở đây dường như là điều đáng hổ thẹn. Điều này không tốt cho danh tiếng của tôi. Và của cô ấy. Và tôi có thể nói là cả cô nữa đấy.”

es: –Tenemos que legitimar esta situación -declaró Rashid, colocando el cenicero en equilibrio sobre su vientre. Sus labios se fruncieron en un pícaro mohín-. La gente empezará a rumorean No es decente que una mujer joven y soltera viva aquí. Mi reputación se resentiría. Por no mencionar la de ella y la tuya, claro.
vi_translation: “We need to legalize this situation,” he said, balancing the ashtray on his stomach. His lips puckered humorously. “People will talk. Having a young unmarried woman living here seems shameful. This is not good for my reputation. And for hers. And I might say, for yours as well.”
tr_translation: “We need to legitimize this situation,” the man was saying now, placing the ashtray on his belly. His lips extended with a mischievous pucker. “Otherwise, rumors will start. A young, single woman living with us is not appropriate. My reputation could be tarnished. So could hers. Even yours.”
es_translation: –We have to legitimize this situation -declared Rashid, balancing the ashtray on his belly. His lips puckered into a mischievous pout-. People will start to gossip. It's not decent for a young, single woman to live here. My reputation would suffer. Not to mention hers and yours, of course.

en: "Anyway," he said at last, fingers drumming his belly, "I can't be blamed. I am a husband. These are the things a husband wonders. But he's lucky he died the way he did. Because if he was here now, if I got my hands on him…" He sucked through his teeth and shook his head.
vi: “Dù sao,” cuối cùng Rasheed nói, gõ ngón tay lên bụng, “Cô cũng không thể trách tôi. Tôi là một người chồng. Đó là những điều mà một người chồng thường băn khoăn. Nhưng hắn ta đã may mắn khi được chết theo kiểu đó. Bởi vì nếu mà hắn ở đây, và tôi có tóm được...” Ông ta khẽ rít qua kẽ răng và lắc đầu.
vi_results: "title": "The Unfaithful Wife", "author": "Nguyễn Nhật Ánh"
tr: “Her neyse,” dedi adam sonunda, parmaklarıyla göbeğinde davul çalarken. “Kusur işlemedik ki. Ben bir kocayım. Her koca merak eder bu tür şeyleri. Ama şansı varmış ki ölüp gitmiş. Çünkü şu an burada olsaydı, onu elime geçirseydim...” Dişlerinin arasından havayı emdi, başını salladı.
es: –En cualquier caso -prosiguió Rashid al fin, tamborileando con los dedos sobre el estómago-, no puedes culparme. Soy tu marido, y un marido se pregunta este tipo de cosas. Pero tuvo suerte de morir, porque si estuviera aquí ahora, si le pusiera las manos encima… -Aspiró una bocanada de aire entre dientes y meneó la cabeza.
vi_translation: “Anyway,” Rasheed finally said, tapping his fingers on his belly, “You can't blame me. I am a husband. These are the things a husband usually worries about. But he was lucky to die that way. Because if he were here, and I caught him...” He hissed softly through his teeth and shook his head.
tr_translation: “Anyway,” said the man finally, drumming on his belly with his fingers. “We haven't committed a sin. I'm a husband. Every husband wonders about these kinds of things. But she was lucky to have died and gone. Because if she were here right now, if I had gotten hold of her...” He sucked in air through his teeth and shook his head.
es_translation: –In any case -Rashid finally continued, drumming his fingers on his stomach-, you can't blame me. I'm your husband, and a husband wonders about these kinds of things. But he was lucky to die, because if he were here now, if I got my hands on him... -He drew a breath through his teeth and shook his head.

en: Later, he mounted her and relieved himself with wordless haste, fully dressed save for histumban, not removed but pulled down to the ankles. When the frantic rocking was over, he rolled off her and was asleep in minutes.
vi: Tối đó, ông ta leo lên người cô và tự thỏa mãn bản thân một cách vội vã, chẳng nói chẳng rằng, để nguyên cả quần áo, trừ có chiếc tumban không cởi ra hẳn mà kéo tụt xuống mắt cá chân. Sau khi cơn vật vã điên cuồng đã qua đi, ông ta buông cô ra và nhanh chóng chìm vào giấc ngủ.
vi_results: "title": "The Tale of Kieu","author": "Nguyen Du"
tr: Daha sonra, kızın üzerine çıktı, tek kelime etmeden boşaldı; bileklerine indirdiği tumban sayılmazsa, bütünüyle giyinikti. Şiddetli, azgın sallantısı bitince yana devrildi, birkaç dakika içinde de uyudu.
es: Más tarde, Rashid se acostó con Laila y se desahogó con mudo apremio, sin molestarse en desvestirse siquiera, limitándose a bajarse el tumban hasta los tobillos. Cuando terminó su frenético meneo, se apartó de ella y se quedó dormido casi al instante.
vi_translation: That night, he climbed on top of her and hastily satisfied himself without saying a word, leaving all his clothes on except for his trousers, which he didn't completely take off but pulled down to his ankles. After the frenzied struggle was over, he let her go and quickly fell asleep.
tr_translation: Then, he got on top of the girl and ejaculated without saying a word; except for the trousers he had pulled down to his wrists, he was fully dressed. When his violent, furious shaking ended, he rolled to the side and fell asleep within a few minutes.
es_translation: Later, Rashid lay down with Laila and vented with mute urgency, not even bothering to undress, merely pulling down his tumban to his ankles. When he finished his frantic thrusting, he moved away from her and fell asleep almost instantly.
st: 'Me o ile a ema' me a imoloha ka potlako, a apere ka ho feletseng bakeng sa histumban, a sa tlosoa empa a hulela maqaqailaneng. Ha a ntse a le lefifing, o ile a mo robatsa mme a robala ka mor'a metsotso e seng mekae.
yo: Lẹ́yìn náà, ó gbé e sókè ó sì tù ara rẹ̀ nínú pẹ̀lú ìkánjú tí kò ní ọ̀rọ̀, ìgbàlà tí ó wọ aṣọ kíkún fún histumban, kò yọ kúrò ṣùgbọ́n ó fà á sọ̀kalẹ̀ sí ẹsẹ̀ ẹsẹ̀. Nígbà tí ìgbóná náà parí, ó yí i padà ó sì sùn láàárín ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀.
tn: Morago ga moo, o ne a mo itlhaganedisa ka bonako, a apara diaparo tsa gagwe ka botlalo, a se ka a di tlosa, mme a digela mo dinaong. Fa a sena go robadiwa, o ne a mo robatsa a bo a robala mo metsotsong e le mmalwa.

en: At the Lahore Gate bus station, near Pol Mahmood Khan in East Kabul, a row of buses sat idling along the curbside. Men in turbans were busy heaving bundles and crates onto bus tops, securing suitcases down with ropes. Inside the station, men stood in a long line at the ticket booth. Burqa-clad women stood in groups and chatted, their belongings piled at their feet. Babies were bounced, children scolded for straying too far.
vi: Tại trạm xe bus cổng Lahore, gần Pol Mahmood Khan, phía Đông Kabul, một hàng dài xe bus đứng đợi bên vỉa hè. Những người đàn ông quấn khăn đang bận rộn nâng đồ lên nóc xe bus và dùng dây thừng buộc chặt những chiếc va li. Trong sân ga, đàn ông xếp hàng dài trước quầy bán vé. Những người phụ nữ mặc áo trùm dài đứng thành từng nhóm nói chuyện với nhau, hành lý của họ để ở dưới chân. Những đứa bé được tung nựng còn đám trẻ con thì bị mắng vì chạy đi quá xa.
vi_results: "title": "The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao","author": "Junot Díaz"
tr: Doğu Kabil’de, Pol Muhammet Han yakınındaki otobüs garında, Lahore Kapısı’nda, boş otobüsler kaldırımın kenarına dizilmişti. Başları türbanlı erkekler harıl harıl eşyaları, denkleri otobüslerin üzerine yerleştiriyor, bavulları sicimlerle bağlıyorlardı. Garın içinde, bilet gişesinin önünde uzun bir erkek kuyruğu oluşmuştu. Burkalı kadınlar küçük gruplar halinde duruyor, gevezelik ediyordu; eşyaları ayaklarının dibine yığılmıştı. Bebekler pışpışlanıyor, çocuklara uzaklaşmamaları tembihleniyordu.
es: En la estación de autobuses de Lahore Gate, cerca de Pol Mahmud Jan, en Kabul este, había una hilera de autobuses aparcados. Hombres con turbante se afanaban en subir cajas y bultos a los tejadillos, donde afianzaban las maletas con cuerdas. Dentro de la estación, había una larga cola de hombres hasta la ventanilla de venta de billetes. También vieron mujeres con burka, charlando en grupos, rodeadas de sus bártulos, mientras acunaban a sus bebés o regañaban a sus hijos por alejarse demasiado.
es_results: "title": "Un buen día en la vida de un cordero", "author": "Khaled Hosseini"
vi_translation: At the Lahore gate bus station, near Pol Mahmood Khan, in the eastern part of Kabul, a long line of buses waited by the sidewalk. Men with turbans were busy lifting luggage onto the roofs of the buses and tying the suitcases tightly with ropes. In the station yard, men lined up in front of the ticket counter. Women in long robes stood in groups talking to each other, their luggage placed at their feet. Babies were being cuddled while children were scolded for running too far.
tr_translation: In East Kabul, at the bus station near Pol Muhammet Khan, at Lahore Gate, empty buses were lined up along the curb. Men with turbans on their heads were busily placing belongings and bundles on top of the buses, tying suitcases with strings. Inside the station, a long line of men had formed in front of the ticket booth. Women in burqas were standing in small groups, chatting; their belongings were piled at their feet. Babies were being soothed, and children were being warned not to wander off.
es_translation: At the Lahore Gate bus station, near Pol Mahmud Jan, in eastern Kabul, there was a row of parked buses. Men with turbans were busy loading boxes and bundles onto the roofs, where they secured the luggage with ropes. Inside the station, there was a long line of men up to the ticket window. They also saw women in burqas, chatting in groups, surrounded by their belongings, while they cradled their babies or scolded their children for straying too far.
st: Seteisheneng sa libese sa Lahore, haufi le Pol Mahmood Khan bochabela Kabul, moleng oa libese o lutse o idling haufi le curbside. Banna ba turban ba ne ba tšoarehile mekoti e boima 'me ba crates holim'a litlhōrō tsa libese, ba securing lisutuk'heise fatše ka lithapo. Ka har'a seteishene, banna ba ne ba eme moleng o molelele ka lebokoseng la litekete. Basali ba burqa-clad ba ne ba eme ka lihlopha 'me ba qoqa, thepa ea bona e bokellana maotong a bona. Bana ba ne ba sa tsebe hore bana ba ne ba le hole haholo.
yo: Ní ibùdókọ̀ ọkọ̀ Lahore Gate, nítòsí Pol Mahmood Khan ní Ìlà Oòrùn Kabul, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ọkọ̀ akẹ́rù jókòó tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ lẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ ẹ̀gbẹ́ ẹ̀gbẹ́. Àwọn ọkùnrin tí wọ́n wọ aṣọ ìbòjú máa ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn ìdì tó wúwo àti àpótí sí orí ọkọ̀ akẹ́rù, tí wọ́n ń fi okùn dáàbò bo àwọn àpótí ọkọ̀. Nínú ibùdó náà, àwọn ọkùnrin dúró ní ìlà gígùn ní ibùdó tíkẹ́ẹ̀tì. Àwọn obìnrin tí wọ́n wọ burqa dúró ní ẹgbẹ́ tí wọ́n sì ń sọ̀rọ̀, àwọn ohun ìní wọn kó jọ ní ẹsẹ̀ wọn. Wọ́n bọ́ sí àwọn ọmọdé, wọ́n bá àwọn ọmọdé wí pé wọ́n ṣìnà jìnnà jù.
tn: Kwa seteišeneng sa bese sa Lahore gate, gaufi le Pol Mahmood Khan kwa Botlhaba jwa Kabul, go ne ga nna le mola wa dibese di ne tsa dula gaufi le curbside. Banna ba ba neng ba le mo go yone ba ne ba na le ditshipi tse di bokete tse di neng di le mo godimo ga bese, ba ne ba rwesa diaparo tse di kwa tlase ka dithapo. Ka fa gare ga ntlo, banna ba ne ba eme ka lobaka lo loleele ba le mo tseleng e e neng e le mo go yone. Basadi ba ba neng ba le mo go yone ba ne ba eme ka ditlhopha mme ba bua ka dilo tse ba di apereng, ba ne ba le mmogo mo dinaong tsa bone. Bana ba ne ba ôna, bana ba ne ba ôna go ôna mo go feteletseng
ty: I te vahi tapearaa pereoo uta taata no Lahore Gate, i pihai iho ia Pol Mahmood Khan i Kabul Hitia o te râ, te parahi ra te hoê anairaa pereoo uta taata i te hiti purumu. Te rave ra te mau tane e ta ratou mau taamu arapoa i te mau taamu arapoa e te mau afata i nia i te mau pereoo uta taata, ma te tamau i te mau afata vairaa ahu i raro a'e i te mau taura. I roto i te vahi tapearaa pereoo auahi, te tia noa ra te mau tane i roto i te hoê reni roa i te fare titeti. Ua ti'a noa te mau vahine e ere i te melo no te Ekalesia i roto i te mau pŭpŭ e ua paraparau, e ua apapa noa ta ratou mau tauihaa i ni'a i to ratou avae. Ua pepe roa te mau aiû, ua tama'ihia te mau tamarii no te mea ua atea roa ratou.
mai: पूर्वी काबुलमे पोल महमूद खानक समीप लाहौर गेट बस अड्डा पर बसक एकटा पंक्ति कर्बसाइडक कातमे निष्क्रिय बैसल छल। पाग पहिरने पुरुष लोकनि बसक चोटी पर गट्ठर आ क्रेट उतारबामे व्यस्त छलाह, सूटकेसकेँ रस्सीसँ नीचा लऽ रहल छलाह। स्टेशनक भीतर टिकट बूथ पर आदमी सभ एकटा नमगर कतारमे ठाढ़ छल। बुर्का पहिरने महिला सभ समूहमे ठाढ़ भऽ गप्प-सप्प करैत छलीह, हुनक समानक ढेर हुनक पैरमे लागल छल। बच्चा सभकेँ उछाल देल गेल, बच्चा सभकेँ बहुत दूर भटकबाक लेल डाँटि देल गेल।
mg: Tao amin'ny fiantsonan'ny fiara fitateram-bahoaka ao Lahore, akaikin'i Pol Mahmood Khan ao atsinanan'i Kabul, nisy fiara fitateram-bahoaka maromaro nipetraka teo amin'ny sisin-dalana. Ireo lehilahy manao fehiloha dia sahirana tamin'ny fandrobàna sy ny boaty teo amin'ny tampon'ny fiara fitateram-bahoaka, ary niaro valizy tamin'ny tady. Tao anatin'ny gara, nisy lehilahy nijoro teo amin'ny filaharana lavabe tao amin'ny trano fivarotana tapakila. Nijoro niaraka tamin'ny vondrona ireo vehivavy Burqa-clad ary niresaka, nivangongo teo amin'ny tongony ny entany. Nokapohina ny zazakely, nobedesina ny ankizy noho ny fihemorana lavitra loatra.

en: You will stay inside your homes at all times. It is not proper for women to wander aimlessly about the streets. If you go outside, you must be accompanied by amahram,a male relative. If you are caught alone on the street, you will be beaten and sent home.
vi: Luôn luôn ở trong nhà. Không được đi lang thang không có mục đích ở trên đường. Nếu đi ra ngoài, phải đi cùng một mahram - một nam giới có quan hệ họ hàng. Nếu bị bắt gặp đi một mình trên phố sẽ bị đánh đòn và bắt đưa về nhà.
vi_results: "title": "The Awakening","author": "Kate Chopin"
tr: Evinizden dışarıya çıkmayacaksınız. Kadınların sokaklarda amaçsızca dolaşması, caiz değildir. Dışarıya çıkarsanız, yanınızda mutlaka bir mahrem, erkek akrabanız bulunacak. Sokakta tek başına yakalanan kadın dövülecek ve evine gönderilecektir.
es: Permaneceréis en vuestras casas. No es decente que las mujeres vaguen por las calles. Si salís, deberéis ir acompañadas de un mahram, un pariente masculino. Si os descubren solas en la calle, seréis azotadas y enviadas a casa.
vi_translation: Always stay inside the house. Do not wander aimlessly on the streets. If you go outside, you must be accompanied by a mahram - a male relative. If caught walking alone on the street, you will be beaten and taken back home.
tr_translation: You will not leave your house. It is not permissible for women to wander aimlessly in the streets. If you go outside, you must be accompanied by a mahram, a male relative. A woman caught alone in the street will be beaten and sent home.
es_translation: You will remain in your houses. It is not decent for women to wander the streets. If you go out, you must be accompanied by a mahram, a male relative. If you are found alone on the street, you will be whipped and sent home.
st: 'Me u tla lula ka tlung ea hao ka linako tsohle. Ho ke ke ha khoneha hore basali ba se ke ba tsamaea literateng tsa bona. Haeba u tsamaea ka ntle, u tlameha ho tsamaea le amahram, mong'a motho e motona. Haeba u iphumana u le mong seterateng, u tla betloa 'me u rometsoe hae.
yo: O máa dúró sínú ilé rẹ ní gbogbo ìgbà. Kò tọ́ fún àwọn obìnrin láti rìn kiri láìní àfojúsùn nípa òpópónà. Ti o ba lọ si ita, o gbọdọ wa ni accompanied nipa amahram, a akọ ibatan. Tí wọ́n bá mú ọ nìkan ní òpópónà, wọ́n máa lù ọ́ kí wọ́n sì rán ọ lọ sílé.
tn: O tshwanetse go nna mo ntlong ya gago nako nngwe le nngwe. Le fa go ntse jalo, ga go a siama gore basadi ba se ka ba tela mo mebileng. Fa o ka ya kwa ntle, o tshwanetse go tsamaya le Amahram, losika lwa monna. Fa o ka tshwarwa o le nosi mo mmileng, o tla betlwa mme o romelwe kwa gae.
ty: E faaea noa outou i roto i to outou mau fare i te mau taime atoa. E ere i te mea tano ia overe haere noa te mau vahine na nia i te purumu ma te ore e imi i te tapao. Mai te peu e e haere outou i rapae, e tia ia outou ia apeehia e te ama iriti rehu, te hoê fetii tane. Mai te peu e o outou ana'e i nia i te purumu, e taparahihia outou e e faaho'ihia outou i te fare.

en: The waiting room at Rabia Balkhi was teeming with women in burqas and their children. The air stank of sweat and unwashed bodies, of feet, urine, cigarette smoke, and antiseptic. Beneath the idle ceiling fan, children chased each other, hopping over the stretched-out legs of dozing fathers.
vi: Phòng chờ ở Rabia Balkhi đông nghẹt những phụ nữ mặc burqa và con cái họ. Không khí nồng nặc mùi mồ hôi, mùi cơ thể không được tắm gội, mùi chân, mùi nước tiểu, mùi thuốc lá và mùi chất khử trùng. Bên dưới cái quạt trần đứng im, đám trẻ con rượt đuối nhau, nhảy qua những đôi chân duỗi dài của các ông bố đang gà gật.
vi_results: "title": "The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao","author": "Junot Díaz"
tr: Rabia Balkhi’nin bekleme salonu burkalı kadınlarla, çocuklarla kaynıyordu. Havada ağır bir ter, yıkanmamış beden, ayak, sidik, sigara ve antiseptik kokusu. Çalışmayan tavan pervanesinin altında, çocuklar birbirini kovalıyor, uyuklayan babaların öne uzanmış ayaklarının üstünden atlıyordu.
es: La sala de espera del Rabia Balji estaba llena de mujeres con burka acompañadas de sus hijos. El aire apestaba a sudor, a cuerpos sucios, pies, orines, humo de cigarrillos y antisépticos. Bajo el lento ventilador del techo, los niños correteaban persiguiéndose, saltando por encima de las piernas estiradas de los padres, que dormitaban en el suelo.
es_results: "title": "The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao", "author": "Junot Díaz"
vi_translation: The waiting room at Rabia Balkhi was crowded with women wearing burqas and their children. The air was thick with the smell of sweat, unwashed bodies, feet, urine, tobacco, and disinfectant. Underneath the still ceiling fan, children chased each other, jumping over the outstretched legs of dozing fathers.
tr_translation: The waiting room of Rabia Balkhi was teeming with women in burqas and children. In the air, there was a heavy smell of sweat, unwashed bodies, feet, urine, cigarettes, and antiseptic. Under the non-working ceiling fan, children were chasing each other, jumping over the outstretched feet of dozing fathers.
es_translation: The waiting room of Rabia Balji was filled with women in burkas accompanied by their children. The air reeked of sweat, dirty bodies, feet, urine, cigarette smoke, and antiseptics. Under the slow ceiling fan, the children ran around chasing each other, jumping over the outstretched legs of the parents, who were dozing on the floor.
st: Sebaka sa ho leta rabia Balkhi se ile sa teaming le basali ba burqas le bana ba bona. Stank ea moea ea mofufutso le 'mele e sa hlatsuoang, maoto, moroto, mosi oa sakerete le antiseptic. Ka tlase ho fan ea lefeela, bana ba lelekisana, ba tlola maoto a otlolohileng a bo-ntate ba dozing.
yo: Yàrá ìdúró ní Rabia Balkhi kún fún àwọn obìnrin nínú burqas àti àwọn ọmọ wọn. Ògùn afẹ́fẹ́ àti àwọn ara tí a kò fọ̀, ẹsẹ̀, ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀, èéfín sìgá, àti antiseptic. Lábẹ́ àwọn olólùfẹ́ àjà tí kò ṣiṣẹ́, àwọn ọmọdé lé ara wọn, wọ́n ń fò lórí ẹsẹ̀ àwọn bàbá tí wọ́n gùn jáde.
tn: Go ne go na le batho ba ba neng ba le teng kwa Rabia Balkhi ba ne ba na le basadi kwa burqas le bana ba bone. Mowa o o phepa le mebele e e sa tlhapiwang, ya maoto, moroto, mosi wa mosi le antiseptic. Mo godimo ga moo, bana ba ne ba feretlhana, ba ne ba tlolatlola maoto a a kwa godimo a borre ba ba neng ba le mo go yone.
ty: Ua î roa te piha tiairaa i Rabia Balkhi i te mau vahine i roto i te mau burqas e ta ratou mau tamarii. Ua rari te mata'i i te hou e te mau tino horoi - ore - hia, te avae, te omaha, te au auahi o te avaava, e te mau tao'a aro ma'i. I raro a'e i te tapo'i fare, ua a'ua'u te mau tamarii te tahi i te tahi, ma te ou'a na ni'a i te avae paruparu o te mau metua tane.

en: "You think I want it this way?" she said. "What do you want me to do? They won't give me what I need. I have no X-ray either, no suction, no oxygen, not even simple antibiotics. When NGOs offer money, the Taliban turn them away. Or they funnel the money to the places that cater to men."
vi: “Bà nghĩ tôi muốn điều này hay sao?” bác sĩ nói. “Bà muốn tôi phải làm gì? Họ không cung cấp cho tôi những thứ tôi cần. Tôi cũng không có máy chụp X-quang, không ống hút, không có bình ô xy, thậm chí đơn giản là thuốc kháng sinh cũng không có. vi_translation: “Do you think I want this?” the doctor said. “What do you want me to do? They don't provide me with the things I need. I don't even have an X-ray machine, no suction, no oxygen tank, not even simple antibiotics. When NGOs offer financial aid, the Taliban either refuse it or divert the funds to places that serve men.”
tr_translation: "Do you think I would want it to be like this?" "What do you expect me to do, then?" "They don't give me the things I need." "I don't even have an X-ray machine; no suction device, no oxygen, not even the simplest antibiotics." "Non-Governmental Organizations offer financial aid, the Taliban rejects it." "Or they divert the money to men's soup kitchens."
es_translation: –Do you think this is my doing? – he replied-. What do you want me to do? They don't give me what I need. I don't have an X-ray machine, suction device, oxygen, or even the most basic antibiotics. When NGOs offer monetary aid, the Taliban reject it. Or they divert the money to places where men are treated.

es: Así que cogieron la pala y la hundieron en la tierra una y otra vez, pero, requemado por el sol, el suelo estaba duro como la roca, compacto, casi petrificado, y no cedía a sus golpes.

vi_translation: Therefore, they continued to dig, but the ground had become as hard as stone, the layers of dust kept accumulating, compressing together, almost turning to stone.
tr_translation: They continued to swing and thrust, but the sun-scorched ground was as hard as rock; the compacted, solidified, almost petrified soil was resisting.
es_translation: So they took the shovel and plunged it into the ground again and again, but, scorched by the sun, the soil was as hard as rock, compact, almost petrified, and did not yield to their blows.

vi_translation: “Pir Panjal. Pakistan,” he said. “The place where I live is called Murree; it is a summer resort, an hour away from Islamabad. There are many hills and it is very green, with lots of trees, situated high above sea level. Therefore, it is very cool here in the summer. A perfect tourist destination.”
tr_translation: “Pir Penjal, Pakistan,” said Tarık. “The name of the place where I live is Murree; it is a resort area an hour away from Islamabad. A mountainous, lush green place; with plenty of trees, quite high above sea level. That's why it's cool in the summers. Perfect for tourists.”
es_translation: –In Pir Panjal, in Pakistan -he replied-. I live in a place called Murri; it is a summer retreat an hour from Islamabad. It is mountainous and very green, with many trees, and it is well above sea level, so it cools down in the summer. Perfect for tourists.

en: There was a leafless tree he climbed every day, where he straddled a branch and watched the refugees lying about in the sun, their sores and stumps in plain view. He watched little emaciated boys carrying water in their jerry cans, gathering dog droppings to make fire, carving toy AK-47s out of wood with dull knives, lugging the sacks of wheat flour that no one could make bread from that held together. All around the refugee town, the wind made the tents flap. It hurled stubbles of weed everywhere, lifted kites flown from the roofs of mud hovels.
en_results: "title": "The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao", "author": "Junot Díaz"
vi: Có một cái cây trụi lá mà anh hay leo hằng ngày, nơi anh ngồi ghếch chân trên một cành cây và nhìn những người tị nạn nằm phơi mình dưới ánh mặt trời, những đôi bàn chân, cẳng chân của họ hiện ra trần trụi. Anh nhìn những đứa bé trai gầy còm đang xách nước trong mấy cái thùng xăng, đang thu nhặt phân chó lại để đốt, đang dùng dao cùn đẽo những khẩu súng đồ chơi AK-47 bằng gỗ, đang kéo lê những túi bột mì mà chẳng ai có thể dùng làm bánh vì đã vón lại thành cục. Xung quanh khu trại tị nạn, gió thổi làm lều bay phần phật. Gió quăng quật các gốc cỏ dại bay khắp mọi nơi, nâng những con diều bay lên từ các mái lều trát bùn.

tr: Her gün tırmandığı, yapraksız bir ağaç vardı; bir dala ata biner gibi oturur, güneşe serilmiş sığınmacıları seyrederdi; yaraları, kopuk uzuvları gözler önünde. Bidonlarla su taşıyan, ateş yakmak için köpek pisliği toplayan, kör bıçaklarla tahtadan oyuncak AK- 47’ler yontan, kimsenin ekmek yapmayı beceremediği, bayat buğday unuyla dolu çuvalları sürükleyen, küçücük, bir deri bir kemik oğlanları seyrederdi. Mülteci kampını dip dibe dolduran çadırlar rüzgârda çırpınırdı. Rüzgâr yabani ot öbeklerini oradan oraya sürükler, çamur mezbelelerin çatısına düşmüş uçurtmaları havalandırırdı.
es: Había un árbol pelado al que trepaba todos los días para sentarse a horcajadas en una rama y contemplar a los refugiados tumbados, exponiendo llagas y muñones al sol. Veía a los niños raquíticos que llevaban agua en bidones, recogían excrementos de perro para encender fuego, tallaban en madera rifles AK-47 de juguete con cuchillos embotados, y arrastraban sacos de harina de trigo, con la que nadie podía amasar un pan decente. El viento azotaba las tiendas. Hacía rodar las matas de hierba por todas partes y levantaba las cometas que se echaban a volar desde los tejados de las casuchas de adobe.
vi_translation: There was a leafless tree that he used to climb every day, where he would sit with his legs dangling on a branch and watch the refugees lying under the sun, their bare feet and legs exposed. He watched the skinny boys carrying water in gasoline cans, collecting dog feces to burn, carving toy AK-47 guns out of wood with blunt knives, and dragging sacks of flour that no one could use for baking because they had clumped together. Around the refugee camp, the wind blew, making the tents flap noisily. The wind tossed the wild grass roots everywhere, lifting kites up from the mud-plastered tent roofs.
tr_translation: There was a leafless tree he climbed every day; he would sit on a branch as if riding a horse and watch the refugees spread out in the sun; their wounds and severed limbs in plain sight. He would watch the tiny, skin-and-bone boys carrying water in jugs, collecting dog feces to start a fire, carving wooden toy AK-47s with blunt knives, dragging sacks full of stale wheat flour that no one could manage to bake into bread. The tents that filled the refugee camp side by side would flutter in the wind. The wind would drag clumps of wild grass from place to place, lifting kites that had fallen onto the roofs of muddy shanties.
es_translation: There was a bare tree that I climbed every day to sit astride a branch and watch the refugees lying down, exposing sores and stumps to the sun. I saw the emaciated children carrying water in jerrycans, collecting dog excrement to light fires, carving toy AK-47 rifles out of wood with blunt knives, and dragging sacks of wheat flour, with which no one could bake a decent bread. The wind whipped the tents. It rolled the tumbleweeds everywhere and lifted the kites that were flown from the rooftops of the adobe shacks.
st: 'Me o ne lifate tse se nang makhasi letsatsi le leng le le leng, moo a ileng a hloa lekala 'me a shebella baphaphathehi ba robetseng letsatsing, liso tsa bona le stumps ka pono e hlakileng. O ile a shebella bashanyana ba emaciated ba jereng metsi ka har'a makhubu a bona a jerry, a bokella li-droppings tsa ntja ho etsa mollo, ho betla li-AK-47 ho tsoa patsi ka lithipa tse lerootho, a kopa mekotla ea phofo ea koro eo ho seng motho ea ka e etsang bohobe ho tsoa ho e ts'oeroeng hammoho. Ho potoloha le toropo ea baphaphathehi, moea o ile oa etsa litente. E ile ea beha li-stubbles tsa mofoka hohle, li-kites tse neng li phahamisitsoe marulelong a hovels seretse.
yo: Igi kan wà tí kò ní ewé tí ó ń gun lójoojúmọ́, níbi tí ó ti ń rìn lórí ẹ̀ka kan tí ó sì ń wo àwọn olùwá-ìsádi tí wọ́n dùbúlẹ̀ kiri nínú oòrùn, ọgbẹ́ àti igi wọn ní ìwòye tó rọrùn. Ó wo àwọn ọmọkùnrin kékeré tí wọ́n ti rẹ̀ tí wọ́n ń gbé omi sínú agolo jerry wọn, tí wọ́n ń kó àwọn ìdọ̀tí ajá jọ láti dáná sun, tí wọ́n ń gbẹ́ AK-47s ìṣeré láti inú igi pẹ̀lú ọ̀bẹ tí kò dára, tí wọ́n ń lu àpò ìyẹ̀fun alikama tí ẹnikẹ́ni kò lè ṣe búrẹ́dì láti inú èyí tí ó wà papọ̀. Ní gbogbo àyíká ìlú àwọn olùwá-ìsádi, afẹ́fẹ́ mú kí àgọ́ náà fọ́. Ó ju ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ èpò níbi gbogbo, ó gbé àwọn ẹyẹ ẹyẹ tí wọ́n fò láti orí òrùlé àwọn òpó ẹ̀rẹ̀.
tn: Go ne go na le setlhare se se nang matlhare letsatsi le letsatsi, kwa a neng a thubega ka teng, mme a bona batshabi ba letse mo letsatsing, diso le dikgong tsa bone ka matlho a a kwa godimo. O ne a lebelela basimane ba ba neng ba na le metsi mo makgwatleng a bone a jerry, a phutha dintšwana go dira molelo, go betla di-AK-47 go tswa mo logong ka dithipa tse di bothithing, a kopa mekotla ya phofo ya korong e e neng e se na ope yo o ka kgonang go dira borotho go tswa mo go tse di neng di tshwerwe mmogo. Go ralala motse wa batshabi, phefo e ne ya dira ditente. E ne e le ditshupa tse di neng di le mo go yone di ne tsa bônwa go tswa mo marulelong a magwata.
ty: Te vai ra te hoê tumu raau aita e rauere o ta ' na e paiuma ra i te mau mahana atoa, i reira to ' na tapearaa i te hoê amaa e to ' na mataitairaa i te feia horo ê e tarava noa ra i nia i te mahana, to ratou mau pepe e mau tumu raau ma te ite - maitai - hia. Ua hi'o noa oia i te mau tamaroa na'ina'i pararai e amo ra i te pape i roto i ta ratou mau punu taipu, ma te haaputuputu i te mau tutae uri no te tupohe i te auahi, ma te tarai i te mau tao'a ha'uti AK-47 i rapae au i te raau e te mau tipi haumani, ma te patia i te mau pute faraoa ota o te ore roa e ti'a i te hoê taata ia hamani i te faraoa. Na te hiti o te oire o te feia i horo ê i to ratou fenua, ua î roa te mau fare ie i te mata'i. Ua taora oia i te aihere i te mau vahi atoa, ma te huti mai i te mau kite mai nia mai i te mau tapo'i fare vari.
mai: एकटा पत्ताविहीन गाछ छल जे ओ रोज चढ़ैत छलाह, जतय ओ एकटा डारिकेँ गला घोंटैत छलाह आ शरणार्थीसभकेँ घाममे पड़ल देखैत छलाह, ओकर घाव आ स्टम्प सादा दृश्यमे छल। ओ देखलनि जे छोट-छोट कमजोर लड़का सभ अपन जेरीक डिब्बामे पानि लऽ जा रहल अछि, आगि बनेबाक लेल कुकुरक बूंद जमा करैत अछि, सुस्त चाकूसँ लकड़ीसँ खेलौना एके-४७ पर नक्काशी करैत अछि, गहूमक आटाक बोरा लऽ रहल अछि जे एक सङ्ग राखल रोटीसँ कियो नहि बना सकैत छल। शरणार्थी शहरक चारूकात बसात तंबूकेँ फड़फड़ाबैत छल। ई सभ ठाम खरपतवारक पराली फेकलक, माटिक खोपड़ीक छतसँ उड़ल पतड़्ग उठा लेलक।
mg: Nisy hazo tsy misy ravina nihanika isan'andro, izay nikirakirany sampana iray ary nijery ireo mpitsoa-ponenana nandry teo amin'ny masoandro, ny fery sy ny foto-kevitr'izy ireo tamin'ny fomba tsotra. Nijery ankizilahy kely nahia nitondra rano tao anatin'ny kapoakan'izy ireo izy, nanangona ny alika nidina mba handrehitra, nanao sary sokitra AK-47 tamin'ny hazo tamin'ny antsy mankaleo, nitondra ny harona feno lafarinina varimbazaha izay tsy nisy olona afaka nanao mofo avy amin'izany niaraka. en: I hope you do not think that I am trying to buy your forgiveness. I hope you will credit me with knowing that your forgiveness is not for sale. It never was. I am merely giving you, if belatedly, what was rightfully yours all along. I was not a dutiful father to you in life. Perhaps in death I can be.
vi: Bố hy vọng rằng con sẽ không nghĩ rằng bố đang cố gắng dùng tiền mua sự tha thứ của con. Bố mong rằng con sẽ tin rằng bố hiểu sự tha thứ của con không phải để mua bán. Không bao giờ như thế cả. Bố chỉ trao cho con, dù chậm, cái phần mà con có quyền được hưởng. Bố đã không là một người bố có trách nhiệm đối với con khi còn sống. Có lẽ bố sẽ làm được điều đó khi đã chết đi rồi.

tr: Umarım, affını parayla satın almaya çalıştığımı düşünmezsin. Umarım hakkımı teslim edersin: seni, bağışlayıcılığının satılık olmadığını bilecek kadar tanıdığımı yani. Asla da olmadı. Sana yalnızca, geç de olsa, baştan beri hakkın olan bir şeyi veriyorum. Yaşarken sana iyi bir baba olamadım. Belki ölümde olabilirim.
es: Espero que no pienses que pretendo comprar tu perdón, porque sé bien que tu perdón no puede comprarse. Simplemente te hago entrega, aunque sea con retraso, de lo que siempre te ha pertenecido por ley. No fui un buen padre para ti en vida. Tal vez pueda serlo tras mi muerte.
vi_translation: Dad hopes that you won't think that he is trying to use money to buy your forgiveness. Dad wishes that you would believe that he understands your forgiveness is not something to be bought. Never like that. Dad is only giving you, albeit late, the part that you have the right to receive. Dad was not a responsible father to you while he was alive. Perhaps he will be able to do that when he is gone.
tr_translation: I hope you don't think I'm trying to buy your forgiveness with money. I hope you acknowledge my point: that I know you well enough to understand your forgiveness is not for sale. It never has been. I'm only giving you something that has been rightfully yours from the beginning, even if it's late. I couldn't be a good father to you while I was alive. Maybe I can be in death.
es_translation: I hope you don't think that I intend to buy your forgiveness, because I know well that your forgiveness cannot be bought. I am simply giving you, albeit belatedly, what has always rightfully belonged to you. I was not a good father to you in life. Perhaps I can be one after my death.

en: May God grant you a long and prosperous life, my daughter. May God give you many healthy and beautiful children. May you find the happiness, peace, and acceptance that I did not give you. Be well. I leave you in the loving hands of God.
vi: Cầu mong Thượng đế ban phước cho con sống lâu và thịnh vượng, cầu Thượng đế ban cho con những đứa trẻ thật khỏe mạnh và xinh đẹp. Cầu mong cho con tìm thấy hạnh phúc, sự bình yên và sự công nhận mà ta đã không dành cho con. Khỏe mạnh con nhé. Ta để con lại trong vòng tay yêu thương của Thượng đế.
vi_results: "title": "The Giving Tree","author": "Shel Silverstein"
tr: Tanrı sana uzun ve refah bir ömür versin, kızım. Tanrı sana bir sürü, birbirinden güzel çocuklar bağışlasın. Sana veremediğim mutluluğu, huzuru, himayeyi bahşetsin. Sağlıcakla kal. Seni Allah’ın müşfik ellerine teslim ediyorum.
es: Que Alá te conceda una vida larga y próspera, hija mía. Que Alá te conceda muchos hijos saludables y hermosos. Que encuentres la felicidad, la paz y la aceptación que yo no te ofrecí. Te dejo en las manos amantes de Alá.
es_results: "title": "Arabian Nights", "author": "One Thousand and One Nights (anonimo, pero traducido por varios autores, incluyendo a Antoine Galland y Richard Francis Burton)"
vi_translation: May God bless you with a long and prosperous life, may God grant you very healthy and beautiful children. May you find happiness, peace, and the recognition that I did not give you. Stay healthy. I leave you in the loving arms of God.
tr_translation: May God grant you a long and prosperous life, my daughter. May God bless you with many beautiful children. May He grant you the happiness, peace, and protection that I could not give you. Stay well. I entrust you to the compassionate hands of God.
es_translation: May Allah grant you a long and prosperous life, my daughter. May Allah grant you many healthy and beautiful children. May you find the happiness, peace, and acceptance that I did not offer you. I leave you in the loving hands of Allah.
